**Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. My little sister was only 11 years old when she got pregnant. It's a hurtful thing. Not only did it hurt her, even me. I was going through a hard time as well. As it is in my culture, once you reach puberty stage, you are supposed to go
to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,
she ended up being pregnant. Today, she's only 16 years old and she has three children. Her first marriage did not survive, nor did her second marriage. On the other side, there is this girl. She's amazing. (Laughter) (Applause) I call her amazing because she is. She's very fabulous. That girl is me. (Laughter) When I was 13 years old, I was told, you are grown up, you have now reached of age, you're supposed to go
to the initiation camp. I was like, "What? I'm not going to go
to the initiation camps." You know what the women said to me? "You are a stupid girl. Stubborn. You do not respect the traditions
of our society, of our community." I said no because I knew
where I was going. I knew what I wanted in life. I had a lot of dreams as a young girl. I wanted to get well educated, to find a decent job in the future. I was imagining myself as a lawyer, seated on that big chair. Those were the imaginations that were going through my mind every day. And I knew that one day, I would contribute something,
a little something to my community. But every day after refusing, women would tell me, "Look at you, you're all grown up.
Your little sister has a baby. What about you?" That was the music
that I was hearing every day, and that is the music
that girls hear every day when they don't do something
that the community needs them to do. When I compared the two stories
between me and my sister, I said, "Why can't I do something? Why can't I change something
that has happened for a long time in our community?" That was when I called other girls just like my sister, who have children, who have been in class but they have
forgotten how to read and write. I said, "Come on, we can 
remind each other how to read and write again, how to hold the pen,
how to read, to hold the book." It was a great time I had with them. Nor did I just learn a little about them, but they were able to tell me
their personal stories, what they were facing every day as young mothers. That was when I was like, 'Why can't we take all these things
that are happening to us and present them and tell our mothers,
our traditional leaders, that these are the wrong things?" It was a scary thing to do, because these traditional leaders, they are already accustomed to the things that have been there for ages. A hard thing to change, but a good thing to try. So we tried. It was very hard, but we pushed. And I'm here to say that in my community, it was the first community after girls pushed so hard to our traditional leader, and our leader stood up for us
and said no girl has to be married before the age of 18. (Applause) In my community, that was the first time a community, they had to call the bylaws, the first bylaw that protected girls in our community. We did not stop there. We forged ahead. We were determined to fight for girls
not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members
of Parliament were entering, we were telling them,
"Would you please support the bill?" And we don't have
much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal
marriage age, from 15 to 18. (Applause) It's a good thing to know
that the bill passed, but let me tell you this: There are countries where 18
is the legal marriage age, but don't we hear cries
of women and girls every day? Every day, girls' lives
are being wasted away. This is high time for leaders
to honor their commitment. In honoring this commitment, it means keeping girls' issues
at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What country is Memory from?
Options: A. Malawi, B. Zambia, C. Tanzania
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the title of the poem written by 13-year-old Eileen Piri from Malawi? Options: A. "Empowering Young Women", B. "I'll Marry When I Want", C. "Malawi's Daughters", D. "The Power of Girls" Correct Option: B
Question 2: At what age did the speaker's sister have three children? Options: A. 13, B. 16, C. 18, D. 20 Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main theme of the poem "I'll Marry When I Want"? Options: A. The importance of tradition and cultural heritage, B. The power of independence and self-determination, C. The impact of poverty on education, D. The role of men in Malawian society Correct Option: B
Question 4: How does the speaker's story contrast with her sister's experience? Options: A. The speaker followed traditional cultural practices, while her sister did not., B. The speaker was forced into marriage, while her sister was not., C. The speaker pursued education and independence, while her sister was forced into marriage and motherhood., D. The speaker's experience was shaped by poverty, while her sister's was not. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the significance of the child marriage bill in Malawi, according to the speaker? Options: A. It is a crucial step towards social change, but requires continued advocacy and education., B. It is unnecessary and will have no impact., C. It is only effective in urban areas., D. It is a failure and should be repealed. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What can be learned from the speaker's experience with grassroots activism and advocacy? Options: A. That social change is impossible without government intervention., B. That grassroots activism is only effective in developing countries., C. That education and empowerment for girls are crucial for social change., D. That male advocates and allies are not necessary for social change. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What tension is highlighted in the speaker's poem and story? Options: A. Between traditional cultural practices and modern values of independence and self-determination., B. Between the importance of education and the role of men in society., C. Between the benefits of early marriage and the consequences of forced marriage., D. Between the impact of poverty on education and the importance of tradition. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the significance of the speaker's vision for the future of girls in Malawi and worldwide? Options: A. That they will continue to face forced marriage and lack of education., B. That they will be empowered to make their own choices and decisions., C. That they will be limited by traditional cultural practices., D. That they will be dependent on men for their well-being. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can the speaker's story and poem be combined with other narratives and research? Options: A. To create a more comprehensive understanding of the issues facing girls in developing countries., B. To promote the importance of tradition and cultural heritage., C. To advocate for the role of men in determining women's lives., D. To emphasize the benefits of early marriage and motherhood. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can be learned from synthesizing the speaker's experience with grassroots activism and advocacy with other social justice movements? Options: A. That social change is impossible without government intervention., B. That grassroots activism is only effective in developing countries., C. That a more effective and sustainable approach to change can be created., D. That male advocates and allies are not necessary for social change. Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is the speaker's critique of traditional cultural practices in Malawi? Options: A. That they are essential for preserving cultural heritage., B. That they perpetuate the oppression and exploitation of girls., C. That they are irrelevant in modern times., D. That they are only problematic in developing countries. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the significance of the new law in Malawi that raised the legal marriage age from 15 to 18? Options: A. It is a crucial step towards social change, but requires continued advocacy and education., B. It is unnecessary and will have no impact., C. It is only effective in urban areas., D. It is a failure and should be repealed. Correct Option: A

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. My little sister was only 11 years old when she got pregnant. It's a hurtful thing. Not only did it hurt her, even me. I was going through a hard time as well. As it is in my culture, once you reach puberty stage, you are supposed to go
to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,
she ended up being pregnant. Today, she's only 16 years old and she has three children. Her first marriage did not survive, nor did her second marriage. On the other side, there is this girl. She's amazing. (Laughter) (Applause) I call her amazing because she is. She's very fabulous. That girl is me. (Laughter) When I was 13 years old, I was told, you are grown up, you have now reached of age, you're supposed to go
to the initiation camp. I was like, "What? I'm not going to go
to the initiation camps." You know what the women said to me? "You are a stupid girl. Stubborn. You do not respect the traditions
of our society, of our community." I said no because I knew
where I was going. I knew what I wanted in life. I had a lot of dreams as a young girl. I wanted to get well educated, to find a decent job in the future. I was imagining myself as a lawyer, seated on that big chair. Those were the imaginations that were going through my mind every day. And I knew that one day, I would contribute something,
a little something to my community. But every day after refusing, women would tell me, "Look at you, you're all grown up.
Your little sister has a baby. What about you?" That was the music
that I was hearing every day, and that is the music
that girls hear every day when they don't do something
that the community needs them to do. When I compared the two stories
between me and my sister, I said, "Why can't I do something? Why can't I change something
that has happened for a long time in our community?" That was when I called other girls just like my sister, who have children, who have been in class but they have
forgotten how to read and write. I said, "Come on, we can 
remind each other how to read and write again, how to hold the pen,
how to read, to hold the book." It was a great time I had with them. Nor did I just learn a little about them, but they were able to tell me
their personal stories, what they were facing every day as young mothers. That was when I was like, 'Why can't we take all these things
that are happening to us and present them and tell our mothers,
our traditional leaders, that these are the wrong things?" It was a scary thing to do, because these traditional leaders, they are already accustomed to the things that have been there for ages. A hard thing to change, but a good thing to try. So we tried. It was very hard, but we pushed. And I'm here to say that in my community, it was the first community after girls pushed so hard to our traditional leader, and our leader stood up for us
and said no girl has to be married before the age of 18. (Applause) In my community, that was the first time a community, they had to call the bylaws, the first bylaw that protected girls in our community. We did not stop there. We forged ahead. We were determined to fight for girls
not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members
of Parliament were entering, we were telling them,
"Would you please support the bill?" And we don't have
much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal
marriage age, from 15 to 18. (Applause) It's a good thing to know
that the bill passed, but let me tell you this: There are countries where 18
is the legal marriage age, but don't we hear cries
of women and girls every day? Every day, girls' lives
are being wasted away. This is high time for leaders
to honor their commitment. In honoring this commitment, it means keeping girls' issues
at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. My little sister was only 11 years old when she got pregnant. It's a hurtful thing. Not only did it hurt her, even me. I was going through a hard time as well. As it is in my culture, once you reach puberty stage, you are supposed to go
to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,
she ended up being pregnant. Today, she's only 16 years old and she has three children. Her first marriage did not survive, nor did her second marriage. On the other side, there is this girl. She's amazing. (Laughter) (Applause) I call her amazing because she is. She's very fabulous. That girl is me. (Laughter) When I was 13 years old, I was told, you are grown up, you have now reached of age, you're supposed to go
to the initiation camp. I was like, "What? I'm not going to go
to the initiation camps." You know what the women said to me? "You are a stupid girl. Stubborn. You do not respect the traditions
of our society, of our community." I said no because I knew
where I was going. I knew what I wanted in life. I had a lot of dreams as a young girl. I wanted to get well educated, to find a decent job in the future. I was imagining myself as a lawyer, seated on that big chair. Those were the imaginations that were going through my mind every day. And I knew that one day, I would contribute something,
a little something to my community. But every day after refusing, women would tell me, "Look at you, you're all grown up.
Your little sister has a baby. What about you?" That was the music
that I was hearing every day, and that is the music
that girls hear every day when they don't do something
that the community needs them to do. When I compared the two stories
between me and my sister, I said, "Why can't I do something? Why can't I change something
that has happened for a long time in our community?" That was when I called other girls just like my sister, who have children, who have been in class but they have
forgotten how to read and write. I said, "Come on, we can 
remind each other how to read and write again, how to hold the pen,
how to read, to hold the book." It was a great time I had with them. Nor did I just learn a little about them, but they were able to tell me
their personal stories, what they were facing every day as young mothers. That was when I was like, 'Why can't we take all these things
that are happening to us and present them and tell our mothers,
our traditional leaders, that these are the wrong things?" It was a scary thing to do, because these traditional leaders, they are already accustomed to the things that have been there for ages. A hard thing to change, but a good thing to try. So we tried. It was very hard, but we pushed. And I'm here to say that in my community, it was the first community after girls pushed so hard to our traditional leader, and our leader stood up for us
and said no girl has to be married before the age of 18. (Applause) In my community, that was the first time a community, they had to call the bylaws, the first bylaw that protected girls in our community. We did not stop there. We forged ahead. We were determined to fight for girls
not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members
of Parliament were entering, we were telling them,
"Would you please support the bill?" And we don't have
much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal
marriage age, from 15 to 18. (Applause) It's a good thing to know
that the bill passed, but let me tell you this: There are countries where 18
is the legal marriage age, but don't we hear cries
of women and girls every day? Every day, girls' lives
are being wasted away. This is high time for leaders
to honor their commitment. In honoring this commitment, it means keeping girls' issues
at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

Question: How many children did Memorys sister have by age 16?
Options: A. 1, B. 3, C. 6
Correct Option: B

Between the importance of education and the role of men in society., C. Between the benefits of early marriage and the consequences of forced marriage., D. Between the impact of poverty on education and the importance of tradition. Correct Option: A

That they will be empowered to make their own choices and decisions., C. That they will be limited by traditional cultural practices., D. That they will be dependent on men for their well-being. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can the speaker's story and poem be combined with other narratives and research? Options: A. To create a more comprehensive understanding of the issues facing girls in developing countries., B. To promote the importance of tradition and cultural heritage., C. To advocate for the role of men in determining women's lives., D. To emphasize the benefits of early marriage and motherhood. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can be learned from synthesizing the speaker's experience with grassroots activism and advocacy with other social justice movements? Options: A. That social change is impossible without government intervention., B. That grassroots activism is only effective in developing countries., C. That a more effective and sustainable approach to change can be created., D. That male advocates and allies are not necessary for social change. Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is the speaker's critique of traditional cultural practices in Malawi? Options: A. That they are essential for preserving cultural heritage., B. That they perpetuate the oppression and exploitation of girls., C. That they are irrelevant in modern times., D. That they are only problematic in developing countries. Correct Option: B

It is a failure and should be repealed. Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 8
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. My little sister was only 11 years old when she got pregnant. It's a hurtful thing. Not only did it hurt her, even me. I was going through a hard time as well. As it is in my culture, once you reach puberty stage, you are supposed to go
to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,
she ended up being pregnant. Today, she's only 16 years old and she has three children. Her first marriage did not survive, nor did her second marriage. On the other side, there is this girl. She's amazing. (Laughter) (Applause) I call her amazing because she is. She's very fabulous. That girl is me. (Laughter) When I was 13 years old, I was told, you are grown up, you have now reached of age, you're supposed to go
to the initiation camp. I was like, "What? I'm not going to go
to the initiation camps." You know what the women said to me? "You are a stupid girl. Stubborn. You do not respect the traditions
of our society, of our community." I said no because I knew
where I was going. I knew what I wanted in life. I had a lot of dreams as a young girl. I wanted to get well educated, to find a decent job in the future. I was imagining myself as a lawyer, seated on that big chair. Those were the imaginations that were going through my mind every day. And I knew that one day, I would contribute something,
a little something to my community. But every day after refusing, women would tell me, "Look at you, you're all grown up.
Your little sister has a baby. What about you?" That was the music
that I was hearing every day, and that is the music
that girls hear every day when they don't do something
that the community needs them to do. When I compared the two stories
between me and my sister, I said, "Why can't I do something? Why can't I change something
that has happened for a long time in our community?" That was when I called other girls just like my sister, who have children, who have been in class but they have
forgotten how to read and write. I said, "Come on, we can 
remind each other how to read and write again, how to hold the pen,
how to read, to hold the book." It was a great time I had with them. Nor did I just learn a little about them, but they were able to tell me
their personal stories, what they were facing every day as young mothers. That was when I was like, 'Why can't we take all these things
that are happening to us and present them and tell our mothers,
our traditional leaders, that these are the wrong things?" It was a scary thing to do, because these traditional leaders, they are already accustomed to the things that have been there for ages. A hard thing to change, but a good thing to try. So we tried. It was very hard, but we pushed. And I'm here to say that in my community, it was the first community after girls pushed so hard to our traditional leader, and our leader stood up for us
and said no girl has to be married before the age of 18. (Applause) In my community, that was the first time a community, they had to call the bylaws, the first bylaw that protected girls in our community. We did not stop there. We forged ahead. We were determined to fight for girls
not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members
of Parliament were entering, we were telling them,
"Would you please support the bill?" And we don't have
much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal
marriage age, from 15 to 18. (Applause) It's a good thing to know
that the bill passed, but let me tell you this: There are countries where 18
is the legal marriage age, but don't we hear cries
of women and girls every day? Every day, girls' lives
are being wasted away. This is high time for leaders
to honor their commitment. In honoring this commitment, it means keeping girls' issues
at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Memory helped her community put a rule in place that no girl could be forced to be married before what age?
Options: A. 15, B. 16, C. 18
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As a wildfire rages through
the grasslands, three lions and three wildebeest
flee for their lives. To escape the inferno, they must cross over to the left bank
of a crocodile-infested river. Fortunately, there happens
to be a raft nearby. It can carry up to two animals at a time, and needs as least one lion
or wildebeest on board to row it across the river. There's just one problem. If the lions ever outnumber the
wildebeest on either side of the river, even for a moment, their instincts will kick in,
and the results won't be pretty. That includes the animals in the boat
when it's on a given side of the river. What's the fastest way for all six animals
to get across without the lions stopping for dinner? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 If you feel stuck on a problem like this, try listing all the decisions you can make
at each point, and the consequences each choice
leads to. For instance, there are five options
for who goes across first: one wildebeest, one lion, two wildebeest, two lions, or one of each. If one animal goes alone, it'll just have to come straight back. And if two wildebeest cross first, the remaining one will immediately
get eaten. So those options are all out. Sending two lions, or one of each animal, can actually both lead to solutions
in the same number of moves. For the sake of time,
we'll focus on the second one. One of each animal crosses. Now, if the wildebeest stays 
and the lion returns, there will be three lions
on the right bank. Bad news for the two remaining wildebeest. So we need to have the lion
stay on the left bank and the wildebeest go back to the right. Now we have the same five options, but with one lion 
already on the left bank. If two wildebeest go,
the one that stays will get eaten, and if one of each animal goes, the wildebeest on the raft
will be outnumbered as soon as it reaches the other side. So that's a dead end, which means that at the third crossing, only the two lions can go. One gets dropped off, leaving two lions on the left bank. The third lion takes the raft back to
the right bank where the wildebeest are waiting. What now? Well, since we've got two lions waiting
on the left bank, the only option is for two wildebeest
to cross. Next, there's no sense in two wildebeest
going back, since that just reverses the last step. And if two lions go back, they'll outnumber the wildebeest
on the right bank. So one lion and one wildebeest
take the raft back leaving us with one of each animal
on the left bank and two of each on the right. Again, there's no point in sending 
the lion-wildebeest pair back, so the next trip should be either
a pair of lions or a pair of wildebeest. If the lions go, they'd eat the wildebeest
on the left, so they stay, and the two wildebeest cross instead. Now we're quite close because the
wildebeest are all where they need to be with safety in numbers. All that's left is for that one lion
to raft back and bring his fellow lions over
one by one. That makes eleven trips total, the smallest number needed
to get everyone across safely. The solution that involves sending both
lions on the first step works similarly, and also takes eleven crossings. The six animals escape unharmed
from the fire just in time and begin their new lives 
across the river. Of course, now that the danger's passed, it remains to be seen how long their
unlikely alliance will last.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why cant the first move be two wildebeest going across?
Options: A. The third wildebeest that doesnt go will get eaten by the three lions, B. The crocodile might eat them, C. The wildebeest might not get along, D. One animal going across is the most efficient move
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many lions and wildebeest need to cross the river to escape the wildfire? Options: A. 2 lions and 2 wildebeest, B. 3 lions and 3 wildebeest, C. 4 lions and 4 wildebeest, D. 5 lions and 5 wildebeest Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the maximum number of animals that the raft can carry at a time? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary goal of the problem? Options: A. To get all the lions across the river first, B. To get all the wildebeest across the river first, C. To find the fastest way to get all six animals across the river without the lions attacking the wildebeest, D. To minimize the number of trips across the river Correct Option: C
Question 4: What approach can be used to solve the problem? Options: A. Trial and error, B. Listing all possible decisions and their consequences at each point, C. Using a random number generator to decide which animals to send across, D. Following a set of predetermined rules Correct Option: B
Question 5: Which of the following real-world scenarios is most similar to the problem? Options: A. A company needs to transport a large number of employees to a conference, but has limited buses., B. A hospital needs to prioritize patients for surgery, but has limited operating rooms., C. A farmer needs to transport a large number of animals to a new farm, but has limited trucks., D. A school needs to schedule classes for students, but has limited classrooms. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What type of problems can the problem-solving approach used in this scenario be applied to? Options: A. Only problems involving animals and rivers, B. Only problems involving limited resources, C. Complex problems that require sequential decision-making, D. Simple problems that require minimal decision-making Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the critical relationship that needs to be considered in the solution? Options: A. The relationship between the number of lions and the number of wildebeest on each side of the river, B. The relationship between the number of trips and the time of day, C. The relationship between the raft's capacity and the number of animals, D. The relationship between the lions' behavior and the wildebeest's behavior Correct Option: A
Question 8: What needs to be analyzed at each step of the solution? Options: A. The number of lions and wildebeest on each side of the river, B. The consequences of each possible decision, C. The time of day and the weather, D. The raft's capacity and the number of animals Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is required to develop a solution to the problem? Options: A. Combining different ideas and strategies, B. Using a single, predetermined approach, C. Ignoring the constraints of the problem, D. Focusing only on the lions' behavior Correct Option: A
Question 10: What needs to be synthesized to develop a solution? Options: A. Information about the raft's capacity, the lions' behavior, and the number of animals, B. Information about the number of lions and wildebeest on each side of the river, C. Information about the time of day and the weather, D. Information about the wildebeest's behavior and the number of trips Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can the solution be evaluated? Options: A. Based on its efficiency, effectiveness, and number of trips, B. Based on the number of lions and wildebeest on each side of the river, C. Based on the time of day and the weather, D. Based on the raft's capacity and the number of animals Correct Option: A
Question 12: What can the problem-solving approach used in this scenario be evaluated based on? Options: A. Its ability to generate optimal solutions and minimize the number of trips, B. Its ability to prioritize the lions' behavior, C. Its ability to ignore the constraints of the problem, D. Its ability to maximize the number of trips Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the minimum number of trips required to get all six animals across the river safely? Options: A. 9, B. 10, C. 11, D. 12 Correct Option: C

However, Question 7 is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ as it discusses the relationship between lions and wildebeest. But it does not specifically address the scenario described in the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As a wildfire rages through
the grasslands, three lions and three wildebeest
flee for their lives. To escape the inferno, they must cross over to the left bank
of a crocodile-infested river. Fortunately, there happens
to be a raft nearby. It can carry up to two animals at a time, and needs as least one lion
or wildebeest on board to row it across the river. There's just one problem. If the lions ever outnumber the
wildebeest on either side of the river, even for a moment, their instincts will kick in,

at each point, and the consequences each choice
leads to. For instance, there are five options
for who goes across first: one wildebeest, one lion, two wildebeest, two lions, or one of each. If one animal goes alone, it'll just have to come straight back. And if two wildebeest cross first, the remaining one will immediately
get eaten. So those options are all out. Sending two lions, or one of each animal, can actually both lead to solutions
in the same number of moves. For the sake of time,
we'll focus on the second one. One of each animal crosses. Now, if the wildebeest stays 
and the lion returns, there will be three lions
on the right bank. Bad news for the two remaining wildebeest. So we need to have the lion
stay on the left bank and the wildebeest go back to the right. Now we have the same five options, but with one lion 
already on the left bank. If two wildebeest go,
the one that stays will get eaten, and if one of each animal goes, the wildebeest on the raft

the right bank where the wildebeest are waiting. What now? Well, since we've got two lions waiting

to raft back and bring his fellow lions over
one by one. That makes eleven trips total, the smallest number needed
to get everyone across safely. The solution that involves sending both
lions on the first step works similarly, and also takes eleven crossings. The six animals escape unharmed
from the fire just in time and begin their new lives 
across the river. Of course, now that the danger's passed, it remains to be seen how long their
unlikely alliance will last.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why cant the first move be two wildebeest going across?
Options: A. The third wildebeest that doesnt go will get eaten by the three lions, B. The crocodile might eat them, C. The wildebeest might not get along, D. One animal going across is the most efficient move
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many lions and wildebeest need to cross the river to escape the wildfire? Options: A. 2 lions and 2 wildebeest, B. 3 lions and 3 wildebeest, C. 4 lions and 4 wildebeest, D. 5 lions and 5 wildebeest Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the maximum number of animals that the raft can carry at a time? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary goal of the problem? Options: A. To get all the lions across the river first, B. To get all the wildebeest across the river first, C. To find the fastest way to get all six animals across the river without the lions attacking the wildebeest, D. To minimize the number of trips across the river Correct Option: C
Question 4: What approach can be used to solve the problem? Options: A. Trial and error, B. Listing all possible decisions and their consequences at each point, C. Using a random number generator to decide which animals to send across, D. Following a set of predetermined rules Correct Option: B
Question 5: Which of the following real-world scenarios is most similar to the problem? Options: A. A company needs to transport a large number of employees to a conference, but has limited buses., B. A hospital needs to prioritize patients for surgery, but has limited operating rooms., C. A farmer needs to transport a large number of animals to a new farm, but has limited trucks., D. A school needs to schedule classes for students, but has limited classrooms. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What type of problems can the problem-solving approach used in this scenario be applied to? Options: A. Only problems involving animals and rivers, B. Only problems involving limited resources, C. Complex problems that require sequential decision-making, D. Simple problems that require minimal decision-making Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the critical relationship that needs to be considered in the solution? Options: A. The relationship between the number of lions and the number of wildebeest on each side of the river, B. The relationship between the number of trips and the time of day, C. The relationship between the raft's capacity and the number of animals, D. The relationship between the lions' behavior and the wildebeest's behavior Correct Option: A
Question 8: What needs to be analyzed at each step of the solution? Options: A. The number of lions and wildebeest on each side of the river, B. The consequences of each possible decision, C. The time of day and the weather, D. The raft's capacity and the number of animals Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is required to develop a solution to the problem? Options: A. Combining different ideas and strategies, B. Using a single, predetermined approach, C. Ignoring the constraints of the problem, D. Focusing only on the lions' behavior Correct Option: A
Question 10: What needs to be synthesized to develop a solution? Options: A. Information about the raft's capacity, the lions' behavior, and the number of animals, B. Information about the number of lions and wildebeest on each side of the river, C. Information about the time of day and the weather, D. Information about the wildebeest's behavior and the number of trips Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can the solution be evaluated? Options: A. Based on its efficiency, effectiveness, and number of trips, B. Based on the number of lions and wildebeest on each side of the river, C. Based on the time of day and the weather, D. Based on the raft's capacity and the number of animals Correct Option: A

Its ability to prioritize the lions' behavior, C. Its ability to ignore the constraints of the problem, D. Its ability to maximize the number of trips Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As a wildfire rages through
the grasslands, three lions and three wildebeest
flee for their lives. To escape the inferno, they must cross over to the left bank
of a crocodile-infested river. Fortunately, there happens
to be a raft nearby. It can carry up to two animals at a time, and needs as least one lion
or wildebeest on board to row it across the river. There's just one problem. If the lions ever outnumber the
wildebeest on either side of the river, even for a moment, their instincts will kick in,
and the results won't be pretty. That includes the animals in the boat
when it's on a given side of the river. What's the fastest way for all six animals
to get across without the lions stopping for dinner? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 If you feel stuck on a problem like this, try listing all the decisions you can make
at each point, and the consequences each choice
leads to. For instance, there are five options
for who goes across first: one wildebeest, one lion, two wildebeest, two lions, or one of each. If one animal goes alone, it'll just have to come straight back. And if two wildebeest cross first, the remaining one will immediately
get eaten. So those options are all out. Sending two lions, or one of each animal, can actually both lead to solutions
in the same number of moves. For the sake of time,
we'll focus on the second one. One of each animal crosses. Now, if the wildebeest stays 
and the lion returns, there will be three lions
on the right bank. Bad news for the two remaining wildebeest. So we need to have the lion
stay on the left bank and the wildebeest go back to the right. Now we have the same five options, but with one lion 
already on the left bank. If two wildebeest go,
the one that stays will get eaten, and if one of each animal goes, the wildebeest on the raft
will be outnumbered as soon as it reaches the other side. So that's a dead end, which means that at the third crossing, only the two lions can go. One gets dropped off, leaving two lions on the left bank. The third lion takes the raft back to
the right bank where the wildebeest are waiting. What now? Well, since we've got two lions waiting
on the left bank, the only option is for two wildebeest
to cross. Next, there's no sense in two wildebeest
going back, since that just reverses the last step. And if two lions go back, they'll outnumber the wildebeest
on the right bank. So one lion and one wildebeest
take the raft back leaving us with one of each animal
on the left bank and two of each on the right. Again, there's no point in sending 
the lion-wildebeest pair back, so the next trip should be either
a pair of lions or a pair of wildebeest. If the lions go, they'd eat the wildebeest
on the left, so they stay, and the two wildebeest cross instead. Now we're quite close because the
wildebeest are all where they need to be with safety in numbers. All that's left is for that one lion
to raft back and bring his fellow lions over
one by one. That makes eleven trips total, the smallest number needed
to get everyone across safely. The solution that involves sending both
lions on the first step works similarly, and also takes eleven crossings. The six animals escape unharmed
from the fire just in time and begin their new lives 
across the river. Of course, now that the danger's passed, it remains to be seen how long their
unlikely alliance will last.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Assuming the correct scenario in question 2, what animal gets dropped off on the left side of the river?
Options: A. The wildebeest, B. The lion, C. They both stay, D. They both go back
Correct Option: B

Question 2: What is the maximum number of animals that the raft can carry at a time? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: B

Correct Option: C

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is a map of Yellowstone National Park. For the most part the park is in Wyoming, but it extends a bit into Montana and Idaho. This little 50 square miles section in Idaho is what concerns us. It's called the zone of death, because of a loophole that exists in the Constitution of the United States. If someone were to exploit that loophole they might be able to get away with murder. Yellowstone was established in 1872 before Wyoming, Idaho, and Montana joined the Union. It's federal land and always has been, but federal land across the U.S. is split up and divided into its corresponding state district courts. Except for Yellowstone. And this is where the loophole begins. Law professor Brian C. Kalt points out in his 2005 paper, "The Perfect Crime", that Yellowstone National Park was assigned fully to Wyoming's district court, even though small portions fall into Montana and Idaho. "Unlike every other district, the district of Wyoming includes land in other states." So Kalt asks the question: what happens if you're caught for a crime you committed in that 50 square mile Idaho region of the park? The first thing law enforcement would do is bring you to Cheyenne, the hub of the district court of Wyoming, because the crime technically happened within Wyoming's jurisdiction. But Article 3 Section 2 of the United States Constitution says that the trial should happen in the state where you committed the crime. If you're a savvy murderer you'll invoke your right to a trial in Idaho. So they bring you back to Idaho no big deal. "In the sixth amendment they said that they would require local juries and the language they use is that the jury has to be from the state and district where the crime was committed." This is called the Vicinage Clause. That leaves you with a sort of venn diagram. You have the right to demand jury from that middle area, where the state in which you committed the crime, that's Idaho, overlaps with the judicial jurisdiction where you committed the crime: the Wyoming district that has jurisdiction over Yellowstone National Park. And here's the problem: "nobody lives there. There's there's no way for them to give you a trial and so I argue they should have to let you go." This could also happen in the Montana portion of the park, except a few dozen people do live there, so a jury could theoretically be called. Kalt has proposed numerous solutions to Congress to fix the loophole, but they have yet to act. "All they have to do is redraw the district line so that the district of Wyoming is Wyoming, the district of Idaho is Idaho, and the district of Montana is Montana and if they do that this all goes away." So if you're planning a gathering of your adversaries, exes, and debtors, maybe try Yosemite.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Yellowstone National Park is mostly in which state?
Options: A. Wyoming, B. Montana, C. Idaho
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year was Yellowstone National Park established? Options: A. 1852, B. 1872, C. 1882, D. 1892 Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who wrote the paper "The Perfect Crime" in 2005, highlighting a loophole in the US Constitution related to Yellowstone National Park? Options: A. Brian C. Kalt, B. Robert J. Smith, C. John D. Doe, D. James A. Johnson Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the primary reason for the loophole in the Constitution related to Yellowstone National Park? Options: A. The park's unique geography, B. The park's jurisdiction being assigned to Wyoming's district court despite extending into other states, C. The park's large size, D. The park's remote location Correct Option: B
Question 4: What would happen if a crime is committed in the Idaho portion of Yellowstone National Park? Options: A. The trial would be held in Idaho, without any jurisdictional issues, B. The trial would be held in Wyoming, and the defendant could not invoke their right to a trial in Idaho, C. The trial would initially be held in Cheyenne, Wyoming, but the defendant could invoke their right to a trial in Idaho, D. The trial would not be held due to the loophole Correct Option: C
Question 5: How could the loophole in the Constitution be exploited by a savvy individual? Options: A. By committing a crime in the Wyoming portion of Yellowstone, B. By committing a crime in the Idaho portion of Yellowstone, potentially allowing the perpetrator to go free, C. By committing a crime in the Montana portion of Yellowstone, D. By committing a crime outside of Yellowstone National Park Correct Option: B
Question 6: What solution has Brian C. Kalt proposed to address the loophole in the Constitution? Options: A. Redrawing state lines, B. Redrawing district lines to match state boundaries, C. Creating a new district court, D. Abolishing the Vicinage Clause Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between Yellowstone's jurisdiction and the Constitution's requirements for trials? Options: A. They are unrelated, B. They are complementary, C. They create a loophole that could be exploited, D. They are identical Correct Option: C
Question 8: What distinguishes the Idaho portion of Yellowstone from the Montana portion in terms of the loophole's impact? Options: A. The Idaho portion has more residents, B. The Montana portion has more residents, C. The Idaho portion lacks residents to form a jury, D. The Montana portion lacks residents to form a jury Correct Option: C
Question 9: (Removed, as it is similar to question 8) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the outcome of applying jurisdictional rules, the Constitution, and the Vicinage Clause to Yellowstone National Park? Options: A. A straightforward resolution, B. An unsolvable problem, C. A complex issue requiring attention and a solution, D. A new constitutional loophole Correct Option: C
Question 11: (Removed, as it is similar to question 12) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 12: What approach does Brian C. Kalt suggest for addressing the constitutional loophole? Options: A. Redrawing district lines only, B. Creating a new district court only, C. Considering multiple solutions, including redrawing district lines, D. Abolishing the Vicinage Clause only Correct Option: C
Question 13: Why does Brian C. Kalt propose redrawing district lines as a solution to the loophole? Options: A. To streamline the judicial process, B. To ensure trials align with constitutional requirements, C. To decrease the population in Idaho's portion of Yellowstone, D. To increase the population in Montana's portion of Yellowstone Correct Option: B
Question 14: How does Brian C. Kalt view the significance of the constitutional loophole? Options: A. As a minor issue not requiring attention, B. As a substantial issue requiring congressional attention, C. As a complex problem with no solution, D. As a simple issue with an obvious solution Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the state in which Yellowstone National Park is mostly located. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 3 does discuss the park's jurisdiction being assigned to Wyoming's district court despite extending into other states.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and intent, I would suggest Question 5, which mentions the Idaho portion of Yellowstone. Although it does not directly ask about the state in which the park is mostly located, it does imply that the park extends into Idaho, which is related to the ground truth MCQ.

That being said, I must emphasize that none of the generated MCQs are a perfect match for the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that Question 5 is the most similar generated MCQ, but with a low confidence level due to the significant differences in question intent and content.

Index: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 2

**Transcript**:
This is a map of Yellowstone National Park. For the most part the park is in Wyoming, but it extends a bit into Montana and Idaho. This little 50 square miles section in Idaho is what concerns us. It's called the zone of death, because of a loophole that exists in the Constitution of the United States. If someone were to exploit that loophole they might be able to get away with murder. Yellowstone was established in 1872 before Wyoming, Idaho, and Montana joined the Union. It's federal land and always has been, but federal land across the U.S. is split up and divided into its corresponding state district courts. Except for Yellowstone. And this is where the loophole begins. Law professor Brian C. Kalt points out in his 2005 paper, "The Perfect Crime", that Yellowstone National Park was assigned fully to Wyoming's district court, even though small portions fall into Montana and Idaho. "Unlike every other district, the district of Wyoming includes land in other states." So Kalt asks the question: what happens if you're caught for a crime you committed in that 50 square mile Idaho region of the park? The first thing law enforcement would do is bring you to Cheyenne, the hub of the district court of Wyoming, because the crime technically happened within Wyoming's jurisdiction. But Article 3 Section 2 of the United States Constitution says that the trial should happen in the state where you committed the crime. If you're a savvy murderer you'll invoke your right to a trial in Idaho. So they bring you back to Idaho no big deal. "In the sixth amendment they said that they would require local juries and the language they use is that the jury has to be from the state and district where the crime was committed." This is called the Vicinage Clause. That leaves you with a sort of venn diagram. You have the right to demand jury from that middle area, where the state in which you committed the crime, that's Idaho, overlaps with the judicial jurisdiction where you committed the crime: the Wyoming district that has jurisdiction over Yellowstone National Park. And here's the problem: "nobody lives there. There's there's no way for them to give you a trial and so I argue they should have to let you go." This could also happen in the Montana portion of the park, except a few dozen people do live there, so a jury could theoretically be called. Kalt has proposed numerous solutions to Congress to fix the loophole, but they have yet to act. "All they have to do is redraw the district line so that the district of Wyoming is Wyoming, the district of Idaho is Idaho, and the district of Montana is Montana and if they do that this all goes away." So if you're planning a gathering of your adversaries, exes, and debtors, maybe try Yosemite.

As a substantial issue requiring congressional attention, C. As a complex problem with no solution, D. As a simple issue with an obvious solution Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is a map of Yellowstone National Park. For the most part the park is in Wyoming, but it extends a bit into Montana and Idaho. This little 50 square miles section in Idaho is what concerns us. It's called the zone of death, because of a loophole that exists in the Constitution of the United States. If someone were to exploit that loophole they might be able to get away with murder. Yellowstone was established in 1872 before Wyoming, Idaho, and Montana joined the Union. It's federal land and always has been, but federal land across the U.S. is split up and divided into its corresponding state district courts. Except for Yellowstone. And this is where the loophole begins. Law professor Brian C. Kalt points out in his 2005 paper, "The Perfect Crime", that Yellowstone National Park was assigned fully to Wyoming's district court, even though small portions fall into Montana and Idaho. "Unlike every other district, the district of Wyoming includes land in other states." So Kalt asks the question: what happens if you're caught for a crime you committed in that 50 square mile Idaho region of the park? The first thing law enforcement would do is bring you to Cheyenne, the hub of the district court of Wyoming, because the crime technically happened within Wyoming's jurisdiction. But Article 3 Section 2 of the United States Constitution says that the trial should happen in the state where you committed the crime. If you're a savvy murderer you'll invoke your right to a trial in Idaho. So they bring you back to Idaho no big deal. "In the sixth amendment they said that they would require local juries and the language they use is that the jury has to be from the state and district where the crime was committed." This is called the Vicinage Clause. That leaves you with a sort of venn diagram. You have the right to demand jury from that middle area, where the state in which you committed the crime, that's Idaho, overlaps with the judicial jurisdiction where you committed the crime: the Wyoming district that has jurisdiction over Yellowstone National Park. And here's the problem: "nobody lives there. There's there's no way for them to give you a trial and so I argue they should have to let you go." This could also happen in the Montana portion of the park, except a few dozen people do live there, so a jury could theoretically be called. Kalt has proposed numerous solutions to Congress to fix the loophole, but they have yet to act. "All they have to do is redraw the district line so that the district of Wyoming is Wyoming, the district of Idaho is Idaho, and the district of Montana is Montana and if they do that this all goes away." So if you're planning a gathering of your adversaries, exes, and debtors, maybe try Yosemite.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which two states does Yellowstone extend into a little bit?
Options: A. Idaho and Montana, B. Idaho and South Dakota, C. Idaho and Utah
Correct Option: A

The trial would be held in Wyoming, and the defendant could not invoke their right to a trial in Idaho, C. The trial would initially be held in Cheyenne, Wyoming, but the defendant could invoke their right to a trial in Idaho, D. The trial would not be held due to the loophole Correct Option: C

Considering multiple solutions, including redrawing district lines, D. Abolishing the Vicinage Clause only Correct Option: C
Question 13: Why does Brian C. Kalt propose redrawing district lines as a solution to the loophole? Options: A. To streamline the judicial process, B. To ensure trials align with constitutional requirements, C. To decrease the population in Idaho's portion of Yellowstone, D. To increase the population in Montana's portion of Yellowstone Correct Option: B

It's called the zone of death, because of a loophole that exists in the Constitution of the United States. If someone were to exploit that loophole they might be able to get away with murder. Yellowstone was established in 1872 before Wyoming, Idaho, and Montana joined the Union. It's federal land and always has been, but federal land across the U.S. is split up and divided into its corresponding state district courts. Except for Yellowstone. And this is where the loophole begins. Law professor Brian C. Kalt points out in his 2005 paper, "The Perfect Crime", that Yellowstone National Park was assigned fully to Wyoming's district court, even though small portions fall into Montana and Idaho. "Unlike every other district, the district of Wyoming includes land in other states." So Kalt asks the question: what happens if you're caught for a crime you committed in that 50 square mile Idaho region of the park? The first thing law enforcement would do is bring you to Cheyenne, the hub of the district court of Wyoming, because the crime technically happened within Wyoming's jurisdiction. But Article 3 Section 2 of the United States Constitution says that the trial should happen in the state where you committed the crime. If you're a savvy murderer you'll invoke your right to a trial in Idaho. So they bring you back to Idaho no big deal. "In the sixth amendment they said that they would require local juries and the language they use is that the jury has to be from the state and district where the crime was committed." This is called the Vicinage Clause. That leaves you with a sort of venn diagram.
